Hinge features were used for each variable to make linear and threshold features
redundant, forming a model with relatively smooth
We set the maximumnumber of background points as 10,000 to produce pseudo-absences
for each IPS, and as much as possible, these background points were close to geographic
(and thus environmental) space containing samples of occurrence data to reduce the
points highly correlated with true probability of presence using the presence
. The other settings were the same as described
We evaluated the predictive precision of Maxent using the area under the curve (AUC)
of the receiver operation characteristic, which regards each value of the prediction result
as a possible threshold, before obtaining the corresponding sensitivity and speci
). However, using AUC only is not enough to
assess the predictive precision of Maxent (
). Here, we used the average omission rates of training occurrence records
to further assess the predictive precision of Maxent for each IPS according to six thresholds
of distribution presence. These thresholds included
xed cumulative value 10, equal training sensitivity and speci
). When AUC values were above 0.7, and meanwhile the average
omission rates of training occurrence records were less than 0.017, the modellings
0.7 was not considered in our downstreamanalyses. The other 386 species were included in
distributed over the Earth based on our occurrence records.
invasive plant expansion at pixel levels from the results of climatic suitability modellings.
indicated that thresholds are problematic and can produce bias in predictions for
multi-species distribution patterns. Here, we used a likelihood approach (
) to assess expansion potential of multi-IPS in each pixel.
